abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the South Sudan Gender
            Support and Development Project for Sudan were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was substantial; Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and grantee performance was also moderately
            unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: In a setting
            such as South Sudan, with extremely weak institutional
            capacity, continuing post-conflict insecurity and serious
            accessibility challenges due to the lack of infrastructure,
            project teams and Bank management should resist government
            pressures to provide nationwide coverage. Ensuring the
            buy-in of state authorities is a challenge when they are
            considerably weaker than central institutions and the
            project or parallel donor activities do not include tangible
            incentives for their participation and leadership. In such a
            low-capacity environment as South Sudan, Bank management
            should not give in to pressure to meet completely
            unrealistic physical construction timetables. Capacity
            cannot be built with one three-year project-in any setting,
            but especially in a new country such as South Sudan where
            donors are starting almost from scratch and capacity needs
            to be cross-sectoral and imbedded in a new Ministry.
